content.title: Quitu Identidad Culinaria, back to the roots of Ecuador's gastronomic identity

introduction.small: In Quito's Las Casas neighbourhood, chef Juan Sebastián Pérez draws from Pre-Columbian traditions to create his own version of national culinary identity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quitu Identidad Culinaria, back to the roots of Ecuador's gastronomic identity

paragraphs.text:
Every morning, chef Juan Sebastián Pérez and his staff come up with a new menu for their restaurant. They base their recipes on Pre-Columbian traditions, add a twist of avant-garde technique, teasing you with high gastronomy. In line with a trend set by young Ecuadorian chefs to go back to their roots, Juan Sebastián Pérez conveys the complex identity of his country through his cooking. Before launching Quitu Identidad Culinaria (Quitus being Quito's founding people in Pre-Columbian times), the chef travelled around the country to better know each ingredient he uses. Green apple-marinated seabass and quinoa ceviche, beetroot pie, smoked duck salad with Andean nuts and a side of pears… Here, everything is fresh and produced by local farmers and families of fishermen. Telling Ecuador's past story with gastronomic creations, Quitu Identidad Culinaria brings forth the promise of a unique experience!

content.title: Casa Gangotena, a daydream in a historical private mansion

introduction.small: In Quito's historic centre on the Plaza San Francisco, a 19thcentury mansion was turned into a luxury boutique hotel, Art Deco setting and latest technologies included.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Gangotena, a daydream in a historical private mansion

paragraphs.text:
Akin to Quito's historic centre, where this boutique hotel set up home, Casa Gangotena radiates of the charm of yesteryear. The Art Deco decoration – murals, painted ceilings, period furniture, gorgeous rugs – and the Neo-Classical architecture are directly inspired by the private mansion's past, from the early 19th century onward. It was made a Relais & Châteaux and listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1978, just like Quito's old town.
Just like its unique setting overlooking the San Francisco square, Casa Gangotena makes room for high-end cuisine, inspired by Ecuador's various regions. While all the major monuments of the country's capital are within a stone's throw, climb up the rooftop to enjoy a cocktail or a café, depending on the time of day. In the backdrop, enjoy an exceptional 360° vista of the whole city, presenting these hallmarks with a different perspective. In daytime, and when skies are clear, squint and you may even be able to see the Cayambe volcano and its white peak in the distance.

content.title: Sea air in Guayaquil

introduction.small: Far from Andean mountains and more than 400 kilometres south of Quito on Ecuador's coastline, Guayaquil is the commercial heart of the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sea air in Guayaquil

paragraphs.text:
Guayaquil, Ecuador's economic capital, as all the traits of a seaside resort where you will enjoy wandering around and feeling sea sprays. Take a stroll on the Malecón 2000, Guayaquil's iconic seafront ending with The Point, Ecuador's tallest skyscraper showcasing a unique twisted structure. You can visit the historic Las Peñas neighbourhood, of particular interest for its colonial and colourful architecture style. Walk along the Calle Numa Pompilio Llona, leading to the Cerro Santa Ana hill covered with houses forming a rainbow-colour pattern. Climb up the 444 steps to its highest point and face the wind on the staircase that will take you to the top of the blue and white El Faro lighthouse. From there, you will enjoy unobstructed views over the entire city centre and the Pacific coast. Adventure lovers will also get on board a genuine pirate ship, infamous Henry Morgan's own vessel. Or why not explore the mangrove surrounding Ecuadorian coasts in a canoe? Get your fill of thrills!

Guayaquil
Ecuador

content.title: Napo Wildlife Center, ecofriendly lodges in the Amazon rainforest

introduction.small: In the Yasuni National Park, the Napo Wildlife Center will offer you a stay that ensures minimal environmental impact, in a fight to preserve its exceptional natural landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Napo Wildlife Center, ecofriendly lodges in the Amazon rainforest

paragraphs.text:
At Napo Wildlife Center in the heart of the Yasuni National Park, the lodges have been built on the banks of a lagoon, which you will discover as you disembark from a dugout canoe off the Napo River. Here you are, Robinson Crusoe for our modern times, with hot running water and electricity to boot. The local Añangu community operates the bungalows according to principles dictated by ecotourism, and with sheer respect for the Amazon rainforest. Furniture has been crafted using wood from sustainable timber forests and energy is being produced by means of solar panels. As for waste water, it is ecologically treated so as not to damage surrounding swamps. An ideal setting for nature lovers and ecotravellers who wish to enjoy the most comfortable amenities available.
As you wake up, the only sounds you will hear will come from the forest: water flowing, birds chirping, otters parading and monkeys calling one another through the foliage… And as soon as you set foot on the terrace, you will revel in the unique panorama that spreads before you: the luxurious Amazon jungle in all its glory.

content.title: Explore Quito's cultural soul

introduction.small: Ecuador's history and cultural traditions are revealed in the various museums and places of worship scattered around Quito.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore Quito's cultural soul

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of La Ronda neighbourhood, the former San Juan de Dios Hospital is a good starting point. It has been converted into the Museo de la Ciudad (City Museum), offering exhibitions that focus on Quito's history, traditions and customs. A special spotlight is given to the evolution of Ecuadorian medicine, since the hospital remained in service for more than 400 years, from 1565 to 1974 exactly. Move on to the numerous places of worship the city counts, offering a true chronological representation of Quito's lifestyles that will then unravel before your eyes. Among the many sites, the Church of San Agustín takes on a particular historical meaning. It is here, in the chapterhouse, that the Declaration of Independence was signed, on August 10th, 1809. A guided tour will take you through the secrets of the “golden convent”, nicknamed after the precious metal's leaves applied on the walls. You could then take a break at the Cafeto coffee shop located nearby, from which to enjoy the view of the Moorish-looking cloister. Explore traditions further at the Iñaquito market, where you will find various stalls selling local produce, herbs, spices and corn. It will also be an opportunity to try some delicious local cuisine, the guatita for instance, a stew of cow tripe, or the encebollado, a tomato fish soup served with onions and cassava.

content.title: Explore Ecuador's green side

introduction.small: Put your hiking boots on and discover the wonders of the Cotopaxi and Yasuni national parks, during a trek from volcanic to Amazonian landscapes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore Ecuador's green side

paragraphs.text:
Its unique biodiversity led Ecuador to protect 44 zones of the country, approximately 20% of the territory. About 80 kilometres south of Quito, the national park surrounding the Cotopaxi volcano welcomes budding adventurers and seasoned hikers alike, for treks of one to several days. It is via a steep yet easily accessible trail – no matter the age – that you will arrive at the José Rivas shelter. However, it will be necessary to acclimate to the high altitude before the journey, as it will end at 4,864 metres above the sea level! Athletes will have the opportunity to climb down on a mountain bike or a horse at the foot of the volcano.
Less elevated and only 250 kilometres away from the capital, the Yasuni National Park is part of the 19 megadiversity areas that exist in the world. During a multi-day immersive trek, hikers will discover the many splendours of the Amazon. Surrounded with turtles, armadillos and toucans, you may even catch sight of a sleeping jaguar in the distance, or a pink dolphin from the banks of the Napo River. Guaranteed change of scenery!

content.title: Traditional and rustic recipes at Tiesto's

introduction.small: It is considered to be one of Ecuador's very best restaurants. In Cuenca, Tiesto's chef Juan Carlos Solano offers family food that pleases tourists and locals alike.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Traditional and rustic recipes at Tiesto's

paragraphs.text:
Eye-catching and colourful tablecloths are just a foretaste of what is to come. At Tiesto's, expect a rustic atmosphere, conveyed with massive exposed beams, ceramic crockery, panama hats and dried corncobs hanging over doorframes for decoration. In the back, right behind the wooden counter of the open-plan kitchen, chef and owner Juan Carlos Solano gets busy. He regularly parts from pots and pans to meet with guests and sometimes even guide their choice depending on one's taste. It will however be tough to resist the chicken curry with macadamia nuts, Tiesto's special veal ribs or the shrimp soup. Some dishes on the menu are served as family-size meals meant to be shared around the table. And do not think twice about the tasting menu: its generous servings are perfect for two!

content.title: Slowing down the pace in Cuenca

introduction.small: The third largest city in Ecuador, Cuenca is located 500 kilometres south of Quito and remains famous for its panama hats. Get a taste of the sweet life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Slowing down the pace in Cuenca

paragraphs.text:
At an altitude of 2,500 metres in the Azuay region, time seems to have stopped. Here, it is customary to take your time. In Cuenca, an urban stroll will never be complete without making your way to one of its markets: for instance, the colourful flower market or the Mercado 10 de Agosto for local flavours, or even the crafts market in which you will find ceramic and wrought items, as well as panama hats – the men's apparel fashion item made of vegetable fibre that, contrary to what the name would let one think, is actually a typically Ecuadorian endeavour.
Stroll around the 16th-century colonial style historic centre, listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, before making your way to the Barranco neighbourhood. From the promenade that runs alongside the Tomebamba River, gaze at the houses suspended on a cliff, with a quimbilito in hand, an Andean pastry made of corn flour and chocolate. Young and old adventurers alike may also visit the Cajas National Park, about 30 kilometres from Cuenca, for a family trek that weaves around a hundred lakes, right in llama country!

Cuenca
Ecuador

content.title: Caffeinated break at Café Tortuga

introduction.small: A favourite hotspot for breakfast lovers in Tena, Café Tortuga is especially renowned for its genuine and homemade Ecuadorian coffee.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Caffeinated break at Café Tortuga

paragraphs.text:
As the name suggests, Café Tortuga is dedicated to turtles. Various iterations of the reptilian animal can be found, from lampshades to wallpapers and even bread baskets. Picturesque charm is revealed through a typical decoration, the red and pale-yellow front, the rustic wooden furniture and bookshelves that favour book loans in all languages. From 7 a.m. onwards, order a Tortuga breakfast to softly start the day: it consists of eggs, cheese, bacon and guacamole topped with cheese cubes, as well as generous servings of batidos, thick fruit-based drinks, freshly squeezed juices and Ecuadorian coffee prepared right before your eyes. At the junction of Tena and Pano rivers, Café Tortuga also works out well when it comes to filling up small hunger levels with a delicious chocolate cake. If the weather is really hot outside, your best bet will be homemade iced tea, supremely enjoyed in front of such a gorgeous setting.

content.title: Tena, gateway to the Amazon

introduction.small: Capital of the Napo region, 190 kilometres southwest of Quito, Tena is a Quechua city and an easy access route to the Amazon rainforest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tena, gateway to the Amazon

paragraphs.text:
Sweaters and other warm articles will soon make way for lighter clothing in Tena. Far from Quito's weather, this Eastern Amazonian town lives under 35°C (95°F) and a humid climate as a result of the surrounding jungle. The city centre was arranged around the walking bridge that gathers the two banks. Bars, restaurants, gardens and monkeys roaming free are all part of the landscape. From the bridge, you will also easily reach the peninsula and the Parque Amazónico, transformed into a botanical garden from which you can observe the Sumaco, Sangay and Reventador volcanoes, some of the most active ones in Ecuador.
What really makes Tena special is its close proximity to the Amazonian jungle. At the confluence of Tena and Pena rivers, which can be navigated on a dugout canoe, the local Quechua communities will offer you to trek to the heart of this primal forest. As you enter deeper and deeper into nature, the cassava and banana plantations will soon be replaced with the climbing plants and other centenary trees of the tropical jungle. Your guides will clear the path, armed with machetes, for you to follow into a denser environment. As night falls, a makeshift camp will shelter you. The sounds of nighttime animals may intimidate some, but this excursion in the heart of the primal forest is well worth it.

www.akangau.com

content.title: Family atmosphere at Hotel Vieja Cuba

introduction.small: In a former colonial mansion in the heart of Quito, Hotel Vieja Cuba reveals enchanting features for competitive prices.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Family atmosphere at Hotel Vieja Cuba

paragraphs.text:
Located in Quito's touristic area close to most shops and boutiques, but also to La Carolina Park and the Museo Nacional del Ecuador, Vieja Cuba is without any doubt one of the best spots to take the pulse of the Ecuadorian capital. Straight away, you will be seduced by the architecture of this charming establishment, looking like a small Hispanic manor. You will distinguish the pastel pink tones of the hotel from afar, nicely embellished by green climbing plants covering the top of the round tower.
Whether as a family or with friends, just drop your suitcase and you will feel right at home in any of the 26 welcoming rooms, arranged with polished wooden floors and stone walls. The staff will go out of its way to make your life easier, find and program visits as well as arrange for transportation across town. You will also have an abundance of choices for each meal, with the Oshira restaurant's Mediterranean-influenced cuisine on one side and Fruta Fresca's on the other. As for those who crave relaxation, they merely need to cross the flower garden and pick up Ecuadorian author Leonardo Valencia's latest novel to enjoy it.

content.title: Mindo, a bird paradise

introduction.small: Budding ornithologists or curious adventurer? The Mindo region, north of equator, will intrigue all wannabe explorers with its cloud forest and exceptional biodiversity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mindo, a bird paradise

paragraphs.text:
Set a course further north! 80 kilometres from Quito, Mindo will strike any nature lover as a true Eldorado. In the cloud forest, in which the foggy mass always linger, birds – and especially hummingbirds – are kings. The best time of day to witness their show, complete with singing and parading, is between 6 and 9 a.m. During the rest of the day, mariposarios (butterfly houses) shelter a wide array of lepidoptera. Climb on board a tarabita, a basket that will take from one valley to another. Be careful if you are subject to heights: you will find yourself in thin air, but with truly stunning panoramas! Back on the ground, follow the road to the waterfalls for a family trek, whether on foot or horseback. Young and old athletes will be able to choose their path: into the trees, in a canoe or tubing down river through a succession of round rubber rings! Set up that headlamp and walk through the forest after dark, surrounded by frogs, bats and other nocturnal mammals. Indiana Jones is nothing compared to you!

www.mindosabinatour.com

content.title: Illa Experience, splendid boutique hotel in the centre of Quito

introduction.small: In the heart of San Marcos, Quito's historic neighbourhood, a large colonial-style house shelters the Illa Experience, one of the capital's trendiest hotels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Illa Experience, splendid boutique hotel in the centre of Quito

paragraphs.text:
The setting is quite idyllic. Only five minutes by foot from the Plaza de la Independencia, the Illa Experience boutique hotel is nestled in an old Quitonian house, built in 1700. Inaugurated in December 2017, the establishment has from the get-go integrated Time Magazine's list of 100 places to visit.
Here, intimacy and splendor reign supreme. Each floor has been carefully thought out and decorated according to various eras in the country's history. The impressive solid wood doors have been donated by a nearby church. Among the stylish four rooms and six suites, you only have to pick a view: the colourful Junín street or the essential Panecillo, famous hill on top of which stands the Virgen de Quito (Quito's Madonna) statue. When comes the time for pre-dinner drinks, you will climb up the hotel's rooftop to enjoy a cocktail – in moderation of course – prepared with local fruits, while gazing at the panorama over the capital's historic neighbourhood. A truly relaxing moment.

content.title: Mitad del Mundo, one foot on each side of the equator

introduction.small: Take a trip to the centre of the Earth and discover the equator's imaginary line, about one-hour drive north of Quito.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mitad del Mundo, one foot on each side of the equator

paragraphs.text:
A yellow line splits the avenue in two. On each side, flowerbeds make up capital letters “N” and “S” for North and South. At the Mitad del Mundo (“Halves of the World”), crossing that line will mean you are basically changing hemispheres. A sign also gives the location's GPS coordinates (0° 00' 00” latitude).
Position yourself on either side of the equator, with one foot on the northern hemisphere and another on the southern one. Located 22 kilometres north of Quito, the monument indicating this imaginary parallel is completed by the Intiñan museum. The latter offers playful experiences linked to the equator, to be carried out yourself. Kids and grown-ups alike will have fun balancing an egg on a nail, or observing in which direction a leaf turns in a water bucket, depending on the hemisphere. All sorts of discoveries await you about local history, fauna and flora, but also about the culture and habitat of local populations. In that respect, a shop graces the museum with local art and craft, mostly created by indigenous communities.

content.title: Termas Papallacta, where relaxation is king

introduction.small: Conceived around hot water springs, the Termas Papallacta hotel offers quiet and intimate stays amid flourishing Andean vegetation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Termas Papallacta, where relaxation is king

Spread between cabañas and wooden bungalows, the 32 rooms all offer underfloor heating, which will make you forget some nights can get chilly. The site is popular with families, and you will choose southernmost cabins to enjoy the perfect quiet. After some mountain exploration, you will recharge your batteries in one of the hot springs available right by your doorstep. Immerged in a pool, make the best of the clear skies to gaze at the unobstructed views over the mountain chain and the Antisana volcano. To further this relaxing experience, Termas Papallacta Spa & Resort also offers hydro massages, pressurized water jets, hammams, as well as Andean mud, chocolate and wine therapy body wraps. The ideal treatment to energize body and mind!

content.title: At Casa de Los Geranios, Ecuadorian specialities take centre stage

introduction.small: In the famous La Ronda neighbourhood, at the heart of Quito's historic centre, Casa de Los Geranios parts with tourist traps and instead offers quality typical dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At Casa de Los Geranios, Ecuadorian specialities take centre stage

paragraphs.text:
Red geraniums growing in flowerpots hang on the window railings of this historic and colourful building located in La Ronda neighbourhood. The restaurant within these walls was therefore quite aptly named Casa de Los Geranios (“House of Geraniums”). Emblematic of Quito, the plant also adorns the inner courtyard. The decoration of the stone walls in this old house of typically Spanish colonial style provides another nod to tradition, which is also found on the menu.
Taste local specialities to your heart's content: grilled cuy (guinea pig) with a peanut sauce, or the lomo especial, an impressive slice of beef covered in ham and cheese and served with lentils. However, the one dish that truly cemented the restaurant's reputation remains its emblematic soup. Made of potatoes, fresh cheese and avocado, it is flambéed in front of you, in its wrought iron pot. A show in itself that finds resonance with the flavours that will totally delight you.

content.title: Mashpi Lodge, in harmony with nature

introduction.small: Located about one hundred kilometres from Quito, the Mashpi Lodge ecological hotel is nestled in the heart of the Chocó forest, in a private nature reserve.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mashpi Lodge, in harmony with nature

paragraphs.text:
Two hours away from Quito, guests are welcome to move further in the jungle. Hidden behind the branches of the tropical forest, Mashpi Lodge will reveal itself. The hotel was conceived to produce a minimal carbon footprint, whilst offering a very high-end service. Chief architect Alfredo Ribadeneira describes it as a “bubble of comfort amidst the jungle”. Food is supplied to the hotel's restaurant by nearby villages, and only organic products are being used. In the same spirit, no trees were cut to build Mashpi Lodge.
Here, amid a 1,200-hectare private nature reserve, you will not notice any other human presence on the whereabouts. Contemplate surrounding nature through the picture windows of the 24 rooms. Fascinated by the show, families of budding observers can spend hours gazing at the courtship rituals of various birds and butterflies above the canopy, listening to equatorial frogs croaking and even making out a few indolent pumas.

content.title: Flourishing nature in the spotlight at the Royal Palm Hotel Galápagos

introduction.small: Close to the Galápagos National Park on the island of Santa Cruz, the Royal Palm Hotel is an oasis of beauty and serenity in a heavenly setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Flourishing nature in the spotlight at the Royal Palm Hotel Galápagos

paragraphs.text:
Nothing could upset the perfection of a stay at the Royal Palm Hotel on Santa Cruz island in the Galápagos archipelago. With no neighbours in sight and far from any road traffic, complete tranquillity is guaranteed in the eight casitas and 13 villas. Good to know for families, some of these cottages are interconnected. Inside, and even though all the rooms at your disposal have been sumptuously arranged, it will be difficult not to focus on the heavenly natural setting surrounding you.
Located about twenty minutes from Puerto Ayora and Baltra airport, the estate of the Royal Palm (not to be mistaken with the international hotel chain) spreads over 195 hectares, as close to the Galápagos National Park as one can get. After a day spent exploring every nook and cranny on the island, take some time to relax by the pool or in the wide park. Isolated from the rest of the world, your only companions will be giant turtles, iguanas and all kinds of birds. The perfect antidote to daily routine!

content.title: High-end culinary fusion at Finch Bay Restaurant

introduction.small: On Santa Cruz island in the Galápagos, the restaurant of the Finch Bay Hotel is considered as one of the best throughout the archipelago, with modern Ecuadorian cuisine and international flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: High-end culinary fusion at Finch Bay Restaurant

The Playa de Los Alemanes (“Beach of the Germans”) spreads in the distance, true beauty of the Santa Cruz island in the Galápagos, and exceptional panorama on view from the dining room of Finch Bay's restaurant. Besides the sound of the crashing waves, only the appetizing smell of dishes being served will interrupt your daydreaming. There will be something for everyone: seafood risotto, Ecuadorian chicken breasts and even some vegetarian options like vegetable and plantain lasagna. As for the mixed ceviche combining octopus, shrimp and fish, there is no better representative of marine flavours.

content.title: Gain some height on board the TelefériQo

introduction.small: Jump several hundred meters high in the Andean air thanks to Quito's cable cars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gain some height on board the TelefériQo

paragraphs.text:
No sooner has it been inaugurated that it was already a landmark of the Ecuadorian landscape. Located on the easternmost side of the city, on the slope of the Pichincha volcano, the TelefériQo (with a capital Q, as in “Quito”) has been in service since 2005. As the day goes on, the queue gets longer and longer in front of the egg-shaped cabins. Once inside, you will rise up above the city for an 18-minute ride. Cruz de Loma is your destination, showcasing a 180° panorama of Quito. It is recommended to go early in the morning, to avoid massive crowds and ensure incredible views. On a clear day, you may even see a few volcanos in the distance, including Cotopaxi, Antisana and Cayambe, among the highest in Ecuador, easily identifiable to their snowy peaks. This breathtaking landscape is also to be taken literary: you will then be standing 4,050 metres high!

content.title: Play out your own Robinson Crusoe experience on Galápagos Islands

introduction.small: A thousand kilometres away from the Ecuadorian coast, do not miss the opportunity to visit the Galápagos Islands, a unique site with an exceptional biosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Play out your own Robinson Crusoe experience on Galápagos Islands

paragraphs.text:
Countless fine sandy beaches abound, but the Galápagos Islands' fauna and flora steal the show. About two hours from Quito by plane, this unique ecosystem spreads over about forty volcanic islands. Expect birds, sealions, sharks, insects, ray fishes, sea and land iguanas as well as giant turtles – in Spanish, “islas de los Galápagos” means “islands of the turtles”. Some 9,000 species live here, and many of them are endemic. The national park (97% of the territory) and the Galápagos marine reserve have therefore been listed by the UNESCO. Day and night, dive with dolphins and sunfishes, or follow in the steps of adventurer biologists (like Charles Darwin, who theorised the origin of species by means of natural selection right here). And after, why not walking or riding a bike looking for carnivorous plants and penguins!

Galápagos Islands
Ecuador

content.title: Cross the Andes on board the Tren Crucero

introduction.small: From the Ecuadorian Andes to the Pacific coast, travel as if in the 19th century, in a locomotive-pulled train.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cross the Andes on board the Tren Crucero

paragraphs.text:
Take your time to explore Ecuadorian landscapes on board a train. At the Eloy Alfaro station, you will settle in comfortably for four days of travel between Quito and Guayaquil, in a train car that recalls of railroad golden ages. In the heart of the Andes, you will make the best of the observation lounge pulled by a real locomotive. The train will stop to let you discover banana, sugarcane and rice plantations, as well as local fauna and flora inhabiting these heights, mountainous forests and seafronts. The cliff-side built railroad will take you through breathtaking panoramas, such as the “volcano avenue”, from which you will make out no less than 10 volcanic craters through the car's windows. In the course of these four days, passengers are invited to soak up Ecuadorian culture through close contact with locals. A truly unforgettable experience, far from traditional tours.

content.title: Discover Quito's historic centre

introduction.small: Roam through the colourful and narrow streets of Quito's centre, looking for the colonial past of the Ecuadorian capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover Quito's historic centre

paragraphs.text:
Start off by exploring the Plaza de la Independencia, facing the Carondelet Palace, which serves as seat of the national government. Every Monday morning at 11 a.m., crowds gather to watch the changing of the presidential guard, which is also an occasion for the President himself to address citizens from his balcony. After 45 minutes of a show that mixes soldiers, horses and drums, it will be time to wander on the old town's main street, Calle Venezuela, all the way to La Ronda. One of Quito's oldest neighbourhoods, bohemian in spirit and romantic, it is always quite lively at night. Try a canelazo, typical hot drink consisting of sugarcane alcohol and cinnamon-boiled water, as you discover the colourful facades lined up on each side of the paved streets.
Do not hesitate and visit the many churches the city counts. They are often adorned with gorgeous frescoes, such as in the gold-leaf-covered central nave of the Iglesia de la Compañia de Jesús (Church of the Society of Jesus). What better way to end your tour than by climbing up one of gothic towers of the Basílica del Sagrada Voto Nacional (Basilica of the National Vow)? From the largest Neogothic basilica of the entire American continent, you will enjoy a totally unique vista over the old town.
